Award.AwardTitle: Molecular dynamics with nuclear quantum effects: bridging classical and quantum regimes
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Sophya Garashchuk, at the University of South Carolina, Columbia, is developing new theoretical methods to analyze the dynamics of molecular motion. This method combines the microscopic behavior of electrons in molecules, treated by quantum mechanics with the motion of the nuclei of the atoms treated by classical mechanics, following that of Isaac Newton. The quantum-mechanical treatment of electrons is important and crucial to understand chemical reactivity, optical, magnetic and other properties of molecules. More importantly these new methods will allow researchers to investigate larger systems such as nanomaterials. Potential applications include photovoltaic materials that convert light to electricity, movement of atoms and molecules through membranes, and isotopic separation.

The scientific goal is to develop a practical methodology for systems of 10-200 atoms, which incorporates Nuclear Quantum Effects (NQEs) for certain nuclei or modes of motion (quantized vibrations, rotations), while they fully interact with the remaining classically-described nuclei. Drawing on the ideas from the quantum trajectory formulation of the Schrodinger equation, we will develop a trajectory-based theoretical framework of including NQEs selectively within a larger molecular environment, transform the concepts into computer codes and through simulations advance our understanding of molecular systems, such as those mentioned above, known to exhibit isotope and other NQEs. Broader educational goals are to train junior researchers in theoretical, computational chemistry, and high performance computing, to facilitate use of computational chemistry tools by experimental colleagues through formal teaching and collaborative projects, and to provide access and training in computational chemistry tools for undergraduate institutions in South Carolina.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported research aiming, broadly speaking, to gain understanding of the nuclear quantum effects on properties of large molecular systems. The motivation comes from current experiments involving manipulation and control of atoms, molecules, electrons and light ? potentially, all in the quantum regime.

Intellectual merit. The method development, based on the Quantum Trajectory Dynamics, was aimed at incroporation of the nuclear quantum effects into molecular dynamics of large molecular systems, something for which currently there are no established simulation methods. The developed methods have been used to study several experimental systems for which the quantum nature of the hydrogen or deuterium nuclei was found experimentally significant. For example, based on theory and simulations, the change in cyrstallinity of polymeric films upon hydrogen/deuterium substitution have been attributed ti the changes in the dipole-dipole interactions. The improved understanding paves the way to use of selective deuteration as a tool to tune the properties of polumeric materials. Another example is the study of the hydrogen and deuterium binding to the metal centers within the metal-organic frameworks. The theoretical analysis has shown which metals (Cu, Ni, Co) work best for this purpose, which helps to develop materials for the hydrogen storage and isotope separation. The nuclear quantum effects have been investigated in other systems, and the results have been disseminated through over a dozen peer-review papers and dozens of seminars and conference presentations by the PI and her group members. The code has been distributed to four research groups and is freely available.

 

Education and workforce training. The PI has developed the graduate/undergraduate course, training experimental researchers in computational chemistry tools and High Performing Computing. The course stimulates computational research and theoretical/experimental collaboration in the department, which now involves eight experimental groups. This award supported workforce development, including three graduate students, a postdoctoral researcher, and a faculty from an HBCU institution.

Participation broadening and outreach. The PI faciliates access to computational chemistry resources for chemists from 8 PUIs, including HBCU and minoroity serving, in the state. The PI and her group members regularly participate in the departmental chemistry outreach program, judge K-12 Science Fair, the University Discovery Day. The PI directs research with undrgraduate students, reviews for the Magellan program for undergraduate research, and interviews candidates to the Top Scholars program at UofSC. These activities broaden participation of underrepresented groups in research and development of the next-generation technologies, and communicate contributions of STEM to the general public of South Carolina, geographically underrepresented in the global research enterprise.
